/* Find the shortest palindrome that begins with a supplied string.
  Algorithm idea is simple:
  - Find the longest postfix of supplied string that is a palindrome.
  - Append to the end of the string reverse of a string prefix that comes before the palindromic suffix.

}

test:
const testByLength = () => {
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(byLength([2, 1, 1, 4, 5, 8, 2, 3])) ===
    JSON.stringify([
      'Eight',
      'Five',
      'Four',
      'Three',
      'Two',
      'Two',
      'One',
      'One',
    ])
  )
  console.assert(JSON.stringify(byLength([])) === JSON.stringify([]))
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(byLength([1, -1, 55])) === JSON.stringify(['One'])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(byLength([1, -1, 3, 2])) ===
    JSON.stringify(['Three', 'Two', 'One'])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(byLength([9, 4, 8])) ===
    JSON.stringify(['Nine', 'Eight', 'Four'])
  )
}

const by_length = (arr) => {
  if (arr.length === 0) {
    return []

  const reversed = sorted.reverse()
  const reversed_length = reversed.length

    const name = ["One", "Two", "Three", "Four", "Five", "Six", "Seven", "Eight", "Nine"][index % 10]

  }

}

const string_xor = (a, b) => {
  const a_int = parseInt(a, 2);

  const result = a_int ^ b_int;
  return result.toString(2);
};

};

<|endoftext|>/*Given a string representing a space separated lowercase letters, return a dictionary
  of the letter with the most repetition and containing the corresponding count.
  If several letters have the same occurrence, return all of them.
  
  Example:
  histogram('a b c') == {'a': 1, 'b': 1, 'c': 1}
  histogram('a b b a') == {'a': 2, 'b': 2}
  histogram('a b c a b') == {'a': 2, 'b': 2}
  histogram('b b b b a') == {'b': 4}
  histogram('') == {}

  */
const histogram = (test) => {
  const histogram = {};
  test.split(' ').forEach((letter) => {
    if (histogram[letter] == undefined) {
      histogram[letter] = 1;
    } else {
      histogram[letter] += 1;
    }
  });
  return histogram;
};

<|endoftext|>/*
  Given a positive integer n, return a sorted list that has the odd numbers in collatz sequence.

  The Collatz conjecture is a conjecture in mathematics that concerns a sequence defined
  as follows: start with any positive integer n. Then each term is obtained from the 
  previous term as follows: if the previous term is even, the next term is one half of 
  the previous term. If the previous term is odd, the next term is 3 times the previous
  term plus 1. The conjecture is that no matter what value of n, the sequence will always reach 1.

  get_odd_collatz(5) returns [1, 5] # The collatz sequence for 5 is [5, 16, 8, 4, 2, 1], so the odd numbers are only 1, and 5.
  */
const get_odd_collatz = (n) => {
  let odd_list = []

      odd_list.push(prev)

  is_sorted([1, 2, 2, 3, 3, 4])  true
  is_sorted([1, 2, 2, 2, 3, 4])  false
  */
const is_sorted = (lst) => {
  const sorted = [...new Set(lst)].sort((a,b) => a-b);
  return sorted.length === lst.length && sorted.every((elem, i) => elem === lst[i]);
};

<|endoftext|>/*Write a function that takes an array of numbers as input and returns 
  the number of elements in the array that are greater than 10 and both 
  first and last digits of a number are odd (1, 3, 5, 7, 9).
  For example:
  special_filter([15, -73, 14, -15]) => 1 
  special_filter([33, -2, -3, 45, 21, 109]) => 2
  */
const special_filter = (nums) => {
  let count = 0;
  for (let i = 0; i < nums.length; i++) {
    if (nums[i] > 10 && nums[i] % 2 === 1 && nums[i] % 10!== 1) {
      count++;
    }
  }
  return count;
};

<|endoftext|>/*
  Evaluates polynomial with coefficients xs at point x.
  return xs[0] + xs[1] * x + xs[1] * x^2 +.... xs[n] * x^n
  */
const poly = (xs, x) => {
  return xs.reduce((prev, item, index) => {
    return prev + item * Math.pow(x, index);
  }, 0);
}

/*
  xs are coefficients of a polynomial.
  findZero find x such that poly(x) = 0.
  findZero returns only only zero point, even if there are many.
  Moreover, findZero only takes list xs having even number of coefficients
  and largest non zero coefficient as it guarantees
  a solution.
  >>> round(findZero([1, 2]), 2) # f(x) = 1 + 2x
  -0.5
  >>> round(findZero([-6, 11, -6, 1]), 2) # (x - 1) * (x - 2) * (x - 3) = -6 + 11x - 6x^2 + x^3
  1.0
  */
const findZero = (xs) => {
  if (xs.length % 2 === 0) {
    let zeroPoint = -1;
    let maxCoefficient = 0;
    for (let i = 0; i < xs.length; i = i + 2) {
      if (poly(xs, i) === 0) {
        zeroPoint = i;
        maxCoefficient = xs[i];
      }
    }
    return zeroPoint + maxCoefficient / Math.pow(xs[zeroPoint], zeroPoint);
  }
  return -1;
}

/*
  xs are coefficients of a polynomial.
  findMax finds largest coefficient of xs.
  findMax returns only largest coefficient, even if there are many.
  Moreover, findMax only takes list xs having even number of coefficients
  and largest non zero coefficient as it guarantees
  a solution.
  >>> round(findMax([1, 2]), 2) # f(x) = 1 + 2x
  2.0
  >>> round(findMax([-6, 11, -6, 1]), 2) # (x - 1) * (x - 2) * (x - 3) = -6 + 11x - 6x^2 + x^3
  1.0
  */
const findMax = (xs) => {
  if (xs.length % 2 === 0) {
    let maxCoefficient = 0;
    for (let i = 0; i < xs.length; i = i + 2) {
      if (poly(xs, i) > maxCoefficient) {
        maxCoefficient = poly(xs, i);
      }
    }
    return maxCoefficient;
  }
  return -1;
}

/*
  xs are coefficients of a polynomial.

  findMin returns only smallest coefficient, even if there are many.
  Moreover, findMin only takes list xs having even number of coefficients
  and smallest non zero coefficient as it guarantees
  a solution.
  >>> round(findMin([1, 2]), 2) # f(x) = 1 + 2x
  1.0
  >>> round(findMin([-6, 11, -6, 1]), 2) # (x - 1) * (x - 2) * (x - 3) = -6 + 11x - 6x^2 + x^3
  1.0
  */
const findMin = (xs) => {
  if (xs.length % 2 === 0) {
    let minCoefficient = xs[0];
    for (let i = 0; i < xs.length; i = i + 2) {
      if (poly(xs, i) < minCoefficient) {

  }

}

<|endoftext|>/* For a given list of input numbers, calculate Mean Absolute Deviation
  around the mean of this dataset.
  Mean Absolute Deviation is the average absolute difference between each
  element and a centerpoint (mean in this case):
  MAD = average | x - x_mean |
  >>> mean_absolute_deviation([1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0])
  1.0
  */
const mean_absolute_deviation = (numbers) => {
  const mean = (numbers) => numbers.reduce((a, b) => a + b, 0) / numbers.length;
  const deviation = (numbers) => {
    const mean = mean(numbers);
    return numbers.map((x) => Math.pow(x - mean, 2)).reduce((a, b) => a + b, 0);
  };

  return true if every opening bracket has a corresponding closing bracket.

  >>> correct_bracketing("(")
  false
  >>> correct_bracketing("()")
  true
  >>> correct_bracketing("(()())")
  true
  >>> correct_bracketing(")(()")
  false
  */
const correct_bracketing = (brackets) => {
  const stack = [];
  let opening_brackets = 0;
  let closing_brackets = 0;
  for (let i = 0; i < brackets.length; i++) {
    const bracket = brackets[i];
    if (bracket === "(") {
      opening_brackets++;
    } else if (bracket === ")") {
      closing_brackets++;
    } else {
      if (opening_brackets!== closing_brackets) {
        return false;
      }
      opening_brackets = 0;
      closing_brackets = 0;
    }
    stack.push(bracket);
  }
  return opening_brackets === closing_brackets;
};

  ASCII codes.

  Examples:
      digit_sum("") => 0
      digit_sum("abAB") => 13
      digit_sum("abcCd") => 67
      digit_sum("helloE") => 69
      digit_sum("woArBld") => 13
      digit_sum("aAaaaXa") => 15
  */
const digit_sum = (s) => {
  let sum = 0;
  for (let i = 0; i < s.length; i += 1) {
    const code = s.charCodeAt(i);
    if (code >= 48 && code <= 57) {
      sum += code - 48;
    }
  }
  return sum;
};

    }

<|endoftext|>/*
  Given list of integers, return list in strange order.
  Strange sorting, is when you start with the minimum value,
  then maximum of the remaining integers, then minimum and so on.

  Examples:
  strange_sort_list([1, 2, 3, 4]) == [1, 4, 2, 3]
  strange_sort_list([5, 5, 5, 5]) == [5, 5, 5, 5]
  strange_sort_list([]) == []
  */
const strange_sort_list = (lst) => {
  const sorted = [];
  for (let i = 0; i < lst.length; i++) {
    sorted.push(lst[i]);
  }
  for (let i = lst.length - 1; i >= 0; i--) {
    sorted.push(lst[i]);
  }
  return sorted;
};

  spaces('orange') == false
  */
const spaces = (string) => {
  let spaces = true;
  for (let i = 0; i < string.length; i++) {
    if (string.charAt(i)!== string.charAt(i).match(/[ \t\n\r]+/g)) {
      spaces = false;
      break;
    }
  }
  return spaces;
};

<|endoftext|>/*Implement a function that takes an non-negative integer and returns an array of the first n
  integers that are prime numbers and less than n.
  for example:
  count_up_to(5) => [2,3]
  count_up_to(11) => [2,3,5,7]
  count_up_to(0) => []
  count_up_to(20) => [2,3,5,7,11,13,17,19]
  count_up_to(1) => []
  count_up_to(18) => [2,3,5,7,11,13,17]
  */
const count_up_to = (n) => {
  let primes = [];
  for (let i = 2; i <= n; i++) {
    if (primes.includes(i)) {
      continue;
    }
    for (let j = 2; j < i; j++) {
      if (i % j === 0) {
        primes.push(i);
        break;
      }
    }
  }
  return primes;
};

  return a + b - multiply(a % 10, b % 10);
